questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of new-onset hoarseness. The patient reports worsening hoarseness over several weeks without a precipitating cause. The patient has had no difficulty swallowing liquids or solids. He has a history of long-standing hypertension, mitral valve stenosis, and a twenty-pack-year smoking history. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an irregular heartbeat. A screening electrocardiogram is shown below. Which of the following structures is most likely implicated in this patient’s symptomatology?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with a longstanding history of hypertension and mitral valve stenosis presents with symptoms of compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely secondary to left atrial enlargement. Left atrial enlargement often results in atrial fibrillation, as detailed on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

Left atrial enlargement can occur secondary to mitral regurgitation, left ventricular dysfunction, mitral stenosis, or volume overload. Over time, increased pressure dilates the left atrium, stretching the conduction fibers and resulting in atrial fibrillation. This enlargement can also compress nearby structures including the esophagus and left recurrent laryngeal nerve, which can manifest as dysphagia or hoarseness, respectively.  



Option Analysis

✅ Left recurrent laryngeal nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Phrenic nerve :
Incorrect: The phrenic nerve is less commonly involved in cases of left atrial enlargement. Symptoms of phrenic nerve injury include exertional dyspnea, recurrent pneumonia, anxiety, insomnia, morning headache, excessive daytime somnolence, orthopnea, fatigue, or difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Esophagus:
Incorrect: The esophagus and the left recurrent laryngeal nerve may be affected in cases of left atrial enlargement. However, this patient does not have evidence of dysphagia, suggesting an absence of esophageal compression.
❌ Pulmonary vein :
Incorrect: Injury to the pulmonary vein can occur following cardiac ablation procedures, which can result in pulmonary hypertension. However, this patient has not undergone cardiac ablation, and he does not have signs of pulmonary hypertension. Hoarseness is more consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: Cardiac ablation procedures can result in direct cardiac damage, including injury to the tricuspid valve. However, this patient has not undergone a cardiac ablation, and hoarseness is more consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. Additionally, injury to the tricuspid valve would manifest with a systolic murmur, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty swallowing. Over the past several weeks, the patient has had the sensation of “food getting stuck” as he swallows. He also has a new history of intermittent “jitteriness.” Medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and esophageal reflux. The patient’s medications include metoprolol, metformin, atorvastatin, and omeprazole. He has a history of medication non-compliance. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 177/92 mmHg. The patient’s physical examination is unremarkable. A portion of the patient’s telemetry strip is demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the affected anatomic site that most likely resulted in this patient’s clinical symptoms?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Level of the left main bronchus

questions.solution:
This patient presents for dysphagia evaluation and is found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation. Although rare, atrial fibrillation and associated left atrial dilation can result in compression of the esophagus and subsequent food impaction.  

The esophagus has multiple compression sites as it courses from the oropharynx to the stomach. Superiorly, the esophagus may constrict as it enters the mediastinum, where the cricopharyngeus muscle may cause constriction. Thoracic constrictions occur where the arch of the aorta crosses the esophagus or at the levels of the left main bronchus and the left atrium. Lastly, the esophagus may constrict crossing the diaphragm.  

Pathologic insults at any anatomic site can ultimately slow the passage of solid foods and liquids. Over time, these insults can lead to esophageal stricture formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Level of the left atrium :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Level of the cricopharyngeal muscle:
Incorrect: Food impaction and stricture formation may result at the esophageal level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the aortic arch :
Incorrect: Aortic arch dilation from aortic dissection or aortic aneurysm may impede the esophagus at this level. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the left main bronchus:
Incorrect: Impingement at the level of the left main bronchus may occur from mass effect due to associated trauma or tumor burden. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the diaphragm:
Incorrect: Esophageal constriction may occur at the diaphragm level due to long-standing esophageal reflux disease and associated stricture formation. Typically, affected individuals will have evidence of untreated disease, including epigastric pain, a metallic taste in the mouth, or a history of gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. This patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman undergoes a cardiac ablation for treatment of symptomatic atrial fibrillation. Several weeks postoperatively, the patient reports shortness of breath with exertion and difficulty initiating a deep breath. She additionally reports a morning headache as well as daytime fatigue. She has not noted any voice changes. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Vitals are within normal limits. Diminished breath sounds are noted over the right lung. No cardiac murmurs are appreciated. A chest radiograph is obtained, as demonstrated below. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?  



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and X-rays findings suggestive of injury to the phrenic nerve following a cardiac ablation procedure. Cardiac ablation is a standard procedure that uses radiofrequency or cryothermal energy to manage supraventricular arrhythmias non-pharmacologically.  

While this procedure is considered low risk, several structures are at risk of injury, including the phrenic nerve, right heart structures, and vascular access sites. Injury to the phrenic nerve results in ipsilateral paralysis of the diaphragm, which can be visualized on chest X-ray as elevation of the hemidiaphragm on the affected side.  Patients with a paralyzed hemidiaphragm can present with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, recurrent pneumonia, anxiety, insomnia, morning headache, excessive daytime somnolence, orthopnea, fatigue, or difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Phrenic nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve does not commonly occur with cardiac ablation procedures. Moreover, unilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve would manifest with hoarseness.
❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: Vascular injury would manifest with evidence of hematoma, swelling, or diminished pulses over the access site. This patient’s chest x-ray suggests injury to a different structure. 
❌ Pulmonary vein :
Incorrect: Injury to the pulmonary vein can occur following cardiac ablation procedures. This patient’s chest x-ray suggests injury to the phrenic nerve, which can result in pulmonary vein stenosis and subsequent pulmonary hypertension. 
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: Direct cardiac damage following cardiac ablation can occur, including injury to the tricuspid valve. However, injury to this structure would manifest with a systolic murmur, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after developing acute onset, left-sided weakness. The patient’s daughter reports she found her mother sitting in a chair, unable to lift her left arm or leg. The patient’s past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 177/86 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Neurologic examination demonstrates a right-sided gaze deviation and 2/5 strength in the left upper and left lower extremity. An initial electrocardiogram is shown below. Which of the following structures of the heart is the most common origin of the thrombus implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons.
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of an ischemic stroke–a major complication of untreated atrial fibrillation, which is depicted on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia in clinical practice and results from unpatterned depolarization of atrial tissues caused by multiple micro-reentry circuits. These reentry circuits can be caused by progressive fibrosis and atrial dilation. Electrocardiographically, atrial fibrillation is characterized by irregular QRS complexes with absent P-waves.   

Diastolic filling and subsequent cardiac output may decrease when rapid ventricular response occurs with rates >100 beats per minute. These changes can result in chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and lightheadedness. In addition, hemostasis in the atria can result in thrombus formation, most commonly at the left atrial appendage, owing to its shape and internal trabeculations.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Left atrial appendage:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right ventricle :
Incorrect: The right ventricle is not the most common site of thrombus formation resulting in ischemic stroke. Thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke do not commonly occur from the right heart unless a patent foramen ovale is present. 
❌ Left ventricle:
Incorrect: Left ventricular aneurysms following myocardial infarction can serve as the site of thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke; however, it is not the most common site of thrombus formation. 
❌ Mitral valve:
Incorrect: The left atrial appendage, not the mitral valve, is the most common site of thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke from atrial fibrillation. 
❌ Tricuspid valve :
Incorrect: The tricuspid valve is not the most common site of thrombus formation resulting in ischemic stroke. Thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke do not commonly occur from the right heart unless a patent foramen ovale is present.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to persistent nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for one day. The patient has been unable to tolerate oral intake. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The patient’s parents report he has been meeting all developmental milestones, but sometimes does not respond when his name is called. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient is actively vomiting and has dry oral mucous membranes. The patient is given intravenous fluids and ondansetron. Several minutes later, the following is observed on telemetry:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following features most likely precipitated this electrocardiographic finding?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy child presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea likely due to a viral gastroenteritis. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, aside from possible concerns for sensorineural hearing loss. This, in conjunction with the telemetry findings of torsade de pointe after ondansetron (which increases the QT interval) administration, raises suspicion for the inherited QT-prolongation disorder Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome.   

Torsade de pointes means “twisting of the points” and is a subtype of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, defined by a ventricular rate >200 beats per minute, undulating QRS axis, and paroxysms of < 90 seconds. If untreated, torsade de pointe can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation, cardiogenic shock, and sudden cardiac death. Overall, the major risk factor for developing torsade de pointes is QT interval prolongation, of which there are numerous causes.  

The most common causes of QT prolongation include electrolyte abnormalities such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia (often precipitated by gastrointestinal losses) and medications such as class IA and IC antiarrhythmics, antidepressants, antidopaminergics, antiemetics or anticonvulsants. Less commonly, congenital conditions such as Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (associated with deafness, autosomal recessive) or Romano-Ward syndrome (normal hearing, autosomal dominant) can cause QT prolongation. Treatment of torsade de pointes involves empiric intravenous magnesium sulfate and cardioversion or overdrive pacing for patients with sustained torsade de pointe and unstable vital signs.   

Option Analysis

✅ Prolonged QT interval  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prolonged PR interval :
Incorrect: Widened QRS complex
❌ Widened QRS complex:
Incorrect: Widened QRS complexes are generally seen when conduction is triggered by the ventricles (in the setting of tachyarrhythmias). Other etiologies include hyperkalemia, sodium channel blockade, hypothermia, and pre-excitation syndromes such as Wolff-Parkinson White.   
❌ T-wave inversion:
Incorrect: T-wave inversions are often the first indicators of ongoing cardiac ischemia. They do not precipitate polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.   
❌ ST-segment depression :
Incorrect: Similar to T-wave inversions, ST-segment depressions are ominous signs of ongoing cardiac ischemia. However, T-wave inversions do not typically precipitate polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female is brought to the emergency department “to rule out a heart attack.” She was sitting in a college class when she experienced sudden tightness in the chest. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes oral contraceptive pills. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/71 mmHg. Physical exam is unremarkable, and electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from wikipedia    

Which of the following features of this electrocardiogram defines this patient's rhythm?

choices.text: Presence of P-waves with normal axis

questions.solution:
This otherwise young, healthy patient presents with chest pain. The electrocardiogram demonstrates a regular rhythm, rate, axis, without ST-segment changes, and a P-wave for every QRS complex. These findings are consistent with normal sinus rhythm.   

Sinus rhythm is the default pacemaker activity of the heart and is defined by several criteria but primarily by the presence of a P-wave for every QRS complex. This finding is reflective of normal SA node activity controlling depolarization of the ventricles via the AV node and His-Purkinje system. Additional electrocardiographic features of this rhythm include a regular rate (60-100 beats/min), a normal P-wave axis (upright in leads I and II, inverted in aVR), constant PR interval, and QRS complex <100 ms.  

A similar rhythm, termed sinus arrhythmia, refers to sinus rhythm with a beat-to-beat variation in the P-P interval, which refers to the time between successive P-waves. Ultimately, this produces an irregular ventricular rate. This arrhythmia is generally non-pathologic and is usually due to changes in vagal tone during the different stages of the respiratory cycle.  

Option Analysis

✅ Presence of P-waves with normal axis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Normal QRS duration:
Incorrect: In general, patients in normal sinus rhythm will have a normal QRS duration (<100ms). However, this feature does not define sinus rhythm.  
❌ Normal QT interval:
Incorrect: The QT interval can provide information regarding the presence of concomitant metabolic disturbances, medication side effects, and inherited QT channelopathy. It can also predict a patient’s risk of developing torsades de pointes. However, a normal QT interval is not the defining characteristic of normal sinus rhythm.
❌ Absence of ST segment changes :
Incorrect: ST segment changes can provide information regarding metabolic disturbance or evidence of ischemia. However, it does not define sinus rhythm. 
❌ Variations in the PR interval:
Incorrect: This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates a P-wave for every QRS complex, normal P-wave axis (upright in leads I and II, inverted in aVR), and a constant PR interval. These findings are consistent with normal sinus rhythm. In general, patients in sinus rhythm will have a consistent PR interval, without beat to beat variation.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a cough and shortness of breath. His partner stated that overnight, the patient started “shaking” and had audible wheezing. Past medical history includes hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 134/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. On physical exam, he is in respiratory distress, with use of accessory muscles of respiration and audible wheezing. Cardiopulmonary examination is notable for rales at the right lung base. Initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following arrhythmias is demonstrated on this patient’s electrocardiogram?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of a COPD exacerbation likely due to community acquired pneumonia. The electrocardiogram demonstrates a regular rhythm, tachycardia, and narrow QRS complexes with the presence of P-waves and T-waves, which is consistent with sinus tachycardia.   

Sinus tachycardia is a type of sinus rhythm defined as a rate greater than 100 beats per minute. On electrocardiogram, it appears as a regular rhythm with P-waves identified before each QRS complex.  The causes of sinus tachycardia are generally divided into non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic causes. Non-pharmacologic etiologies include exercise, sepsis, hyperthyroidism, pain, anxiety, volume loss, pulmonary embolism, and cardiogenic shock. Pharmacologic etiologies include ꞵ-agonists, sympathomimetics, caffeine, and antimuscarinics.  

In severe cases, sinus tachycardia actually decreases diastolic filling time, resulting in decreased cardiac output and tissue perfusion. Treatment is aimed at correcting the underlying etiology, such as via fluid repletion in low volume states.  



Option Analysis

✅ Sinus tachycardia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrial flutter  :
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is defined by atrial depolarization occurring at a rate of 250 to 350 beats/min. It is usually caused by an atrial reentry circuit that runs around the tricuspid annulus. The condition is characterized by "flutter waves,” which have a sawtooth appearance, and the presence of multiple P-waves between QRS complexes. 
❌ Multifocal atrial tachycardia :
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Patients with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia. In contrast, this patient’s rhythm is regular, and the P-waves are of similar morphology.   
❌ Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is defined as an abnormally fast heart rate with irregularly irregular QRS complexes and absent P-waves. In contrast, this patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates regular rhythm and normal P-waves.  
❌ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia :
Incorrect: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, also referred to AV-nodal reentrant tachycardia, manifests with a regular rate, narrow QRS complexes, and absent P-waves. The presence of P-waves in this patient’s electrocardiogram precludes this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old female presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and lightheadedness. The patient’s symptoms started an hour ago while she was watching television at home. She had a similar episode that occurred several weeks ago and resolved without medical intervention. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is a non-smoker and drinks a glass of wine during the weekend. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 122/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is otherwise unremarkable, and initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lightheadedness, shortness of breath, and an electrocardiogram demonstrating an irregularly irregular fast rhythm, without identifiable P-waves. These findings are consistent with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Of the sequelae listed, patients with atrial fibrillation are at highest risk of thromboembolic events.   

Patients with atrial fibrillation are at risk for several complications. Most notably, prolonged atrial fibrillation results in hemostasis, as blood is no longer pumped effectively throughout the body. Thrombi can then form (most commonly on the left atrial appendage), dislodge, and then travel to the brain resulting in embolic stroke. Prolonged atrial fibrillation also places patients at risk for high output cardiac failure and dilated cardiomyopathy. Additional complications include chronic kidney disease, myocardial infarction, and silent ischemia of other organ systems.

Management of atrial fibrillation is targeted at identifying the underlying etiology, achieving rate and rhythm control, and starting anticoagulation. Rate and rhythm control is achieved through the use of calcium channel blockers (e.g. diltiazem) or beta blockers (e.g. metoprolol). The need for anticoagulation is evaluated by calculating a patient's CHADs-VASc score, which takes into account a patient's history of hypertension, congestive heart failure, diabetes, stroke, as well as sex and age. Patients with appropriate risk factors should be started on an anticoagulation regimen.    



Option Analysis

✅ Thromboembolic stroke :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ischemic stroke :
Incorrect: Cerebral ischemia can result from atrial fibrillation due to decreased cardiac output during episodes with rapid ventricular response. However, the risk associated with thromboembolic stroke is higher. 
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy :
Incorrect: High output congestive heart failure and dilated cardiomyopathy may occur in patients with long-standing atrial fibrillation. However, the risk of developing these conditions is not as high as that of developing a thromboembolic stroke. 
❌ Chronic kidney disease :
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation can cause emboli to be released from the heart, potentially leading to renal infarction. Overtime, these infarctions can progress to chronic kidney disease. However, the risk of this complication is overall less than that of thromboembolic stroke.
❌ Myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Demand ischemia and myocardial infarction may result from prolonged episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. In contrast, this complication is less likely to occur during paroxysmal atrial fibrillation or atrial fibrillation without rapid ventricular response. Overall, amongst patients with atrial fibrillation, the risk of myocardial infarction is less than that of thromboembolic stroke.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic with chest discomfort. Over the past week he has felt heart palpitations that occur multiple times per day. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or lightheadedness. Medical history is significant for hypertension, coronary artery disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and myasthenia gravis. He is recovering from a recent myasthenia gravis flare characterized by double vision and fatigable chewing. Medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, carvedilol, terazosin, and pyridostigmine. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Physical exam shows mild bilateral ptosis and a regularly irregular heartbeat. ECG is obtained and shows the following:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s ECG findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with palpitations caused by second-degree Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) atrioventricular (AV) block, as seen on ECG. Second-degree type I AV block is characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until one beat is “dropped.” This dropped beat is identified by a P wave not followed by a QRS complex, which manifests as a regularly irregular heart rhythm on auscultation. In contrast, with Mobitz type II, PR intervals remain the same while beats are dropped, representing a failing AV conduction system (“all-or-nothing”) that requires pacemaker placement. Compared to Mobitz type II, Mobitz type I is usually benign and does not require treatment.  



AV block may be a normal variant and is found at a higher rate in conditioned endurance athletes. Pathologic causes of second-degree AV block include myocardial infarction (the AV node is supplied by the right coronary artery, therefore AV blocks are most often associated with inferior wall MIs), electrolyte disturbances (hyperkalemia), and medications.  

This patient is taking two medications that affect AV node conduction: carvedilol (through β1 receptor antagonism) and pyridostigmine (through acetylcholinesterase inhibition, leading to increased ACh and heightened parasympathetic tone). His pyridostigmine dose was likely increased during his recent myasthenia gravis flare, and therefore it is the most likely cause of his AV block. Decreasing his dose to prior levels should resolve the AV block and his palpitations.  

Option Analysis

❌ β1 receptor agonism:
Incorrect: β1 receptor agonists like dobutamine cause increased cardiac conduction and automaticity of the atrioventricular node. Conversely, AV block may be caused by β1 receptor antagonists, including metoprolol (β1-specific antagonist) and carvedilol (mixed ɑ1/β1/β2 antagonist).  
❌ Myocardial calcium-channel activation:
Incorrect: Amlodipine lowers blood pressure via angioselective calcium channel blockade, inhibiting vascular smooth muscle cell contraction and causing vasodilation with reduced peripheral vascular resistance. Amlodipine has not been shown to impair AV node conduction, as opposed to the non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, such as verapamil and diltiazem.  
✅ Acetylcholinesterase inhibition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase agonism:
Incorrect: Digoxin acts through antagonism of the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase in the myocardium, leading to increased intracellular calcium concentration and prolongation of phase 4 and phase 0 of the cardiac action potential. This antagonism results in decreased heart rate and decreased AV node conduction velocity, which can cause AV block.  
❌ ɑ1 receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: Terazosin is an ɑ1 receptor antagonist that improves symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by blocking smooth muscle contraction in the prostate and urethra, thereby easing urination. However, ɑ1 receptors are not involved in the development of cardiac conduction blocks.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain. He was sitting at home watching television when he noticed the pain, characterized as a sharp pressure-like sensation in the left side of his chest. He is having difficulty catching his breath. Medical history is significant for hypertension, COPD, chronic kidney disease, and coronary artery disease. He takes amlodipine, lisinopril, aspirin, salmeterol, and albuterol. His father died from a heart attack at age 50. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and drinks occasionally. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. He appears pale and diaphoretic. Physical exam shows a holosystolic murmur at the left mid sternal border that increases with supine leg raise. Lung examination is normal. An ECG is obtained and shows the following:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). Pulmonary embolism occurs when a distal thrombus, usually from the deep veins of the legs (DVT), dislodges and enters the pulmonary circulation through the right side of the heart and into the pulmonary arteries. Symptoms include sudden, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, and hypoxemia. If the PE is large enough, blood cannot pass through to the left side of the heart, and the decreased left ventricular preload reduces cardiac output, causing severe hypotension, as in this patient. Since the outflow of the right ventricle (RV) is blocked by a clot, the pressure in the RV suddenly increases (causing the murmur of tricuspid regurgitation) and the RV wall stretches, which stretches cardiac conduction fibers, delaying ventricular conduction in the right side of the heart. On ECG, this appears as a right bundle branch block (RBBB).  

RBBB is recognized on ECG by a broad QRS ( >120 msec), RSR’ pattern in V1-3 (‘M-shaped’ QRS complex) and wide, slurred S wave in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-V6):  



Other causes of RBBB include pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), cor pulmonale (from COPD or interstitial lung disease), and, rarely, myocardial infarction (the right bundle branch is supplied from septal perforators of the LAD coronary artery).    

Left bundle branch block (LBBB) occurs on the left side of the heart, and usually develops over time in the setting of long standing hypertension and coronary artery disease. The left bundle is supplied by the left anterior descending artery (LAD), thus LBBB can sometimes occur in the setting of an acute anterior myocardial infarction. Compared to RBBB, LBBB on ECG goes in the opposite direction with a dominant S wave in V1 and broad monophasic R waves in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-V6):  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Acute myocardial infarction is typically associated with a new left bundle branch block. Symptoms include chest pain radiating to the jaw, sweating, and shortness of breath. The left-sided heart dysfunction would cause fluid backup and crackles on lung auscultation.  
✅ Acute pulmonary embolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cor pulmonale:
Incorrect: Cor pulmonale refers to pulmonary hypertension with right ventricular dysfunction (often associated with a right bundle branch block on ECG) due to chronic lung disease. This process is chronic and develops over months to years, unlike an acute pulmonary embolism.   
❌ Pulmonary arterial hypertension:
Incorrect: Pulmonary arterial hypertension refers to elevated pressures in the pulmonary artery. Over time, this pressure can lead to right-sided heart failure and can cause a right bundle branch block on ECG. However, it would not suddenly cause chest pain.  
❌ COPD exacerbation:
Incorrect: COPD exacerbation is characterized by acutely worsened cough, increased sputum, or sputum quality change with new shortness of breath. Lung auscultation would reveal diminished breath sounds with wheezes throughout.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a near syncopal episode. The patient was outside mowing the lawn when he felt sudden-onset light-headedness, dizziness, and palpitations. The symptoms lasted approximately 30 seconds. He has no significant medical history and does not take any medications. The patient was adopted and does not know his biological family’s past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits, and cardiopulmonary exam is without evidence of gallops, rubs, or murmurs. The initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below.  

 


Which of the following best describes the inheritance pattern of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy male presents after a near syncopal episode with associated light-headedness, dizziness, and palpitations. The electrocardiogram demonstrates a prolonged QT interval of approximately 640 ms. These findings are concerning for the disorder Romano-Ward syndrome, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.   

There are multiple inherited QT prolongation syndromes, although the two most common are Romano-Ward syndrome and Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome. Both diseases are due to potassium or sodium channelopathies, which result in abnormal flow and transport of these positively charged ions during repolarization of the action potential, resulting in QT prolongation. Under cardiac stress, or with an additional QT prolongation insult (e.g. concomitant use of QT prolonging medication), patients with these disorders can degenerate into dangerous arrhythmias such as polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and sudden cardiac death.   

These disorders may present similarly, with some patients being discovered incidentally on routine ECG testing or after a presyncopal/syncopal episode. These disorders can be differentiated by the presence of sensorineural hearing loss, which is only present with Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome. Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, whereas Romano-Ward syndrome is inherited in autosomal dominant fashion.   

Option Analysis

✅ Autosomal dominant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ X-linked recessive:
Incorrect: QT prolongation syndromes are inherited in an autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive fashion. Examples of X-linked recessive diseases include Fabry disease, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, Hemophilia A and B, as well as Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy.   
❌ Autosomal recessive:
Incorrect: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is an inherited QT prolongation syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome can be differentiated from the more common Romano-Ward syndrome by a clinical history of sensorineural hearing loss, which this patient lacks.   
❌ X-linked dominant :
Incorrect: Disorders that are x-linked dominant include Alport syndrome, Rett syndrome, and Fragile X syndrome. QT prolongation syndromes are not typically inherited in a X-linked autosomal dominant pattern.  
❌ Mitochondrial :
Incorrect: Inherited mitochondrial disorders include neurodegenerative diseases as well as inherited forms of cardiovascular disease. In contrast, QT prolongation syndromes are not typically inherited in this pattern.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department after having an abnormal electrocardiogram during a routine outpatient visit. He is currently training for a marathon and had a pre-screening evaluation performed today. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit substances. Past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which he takes levothyroxine. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 52/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mmHg. Physical examination is significant for a well-conditioned male in no acute distress without evidence of gallops, rubs, or murmurs on cardiac auscultation. Electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons    

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s electrocardiographic findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is currently training for a marathon and presents with an electrocardiogram demonstrating sinus bradycardia. In the absence of other underlying factors, the sinus bradycardia is most likely due to increased vagal tone from physical conditioning.  

Sinus bradycardia is characterized by sinus rhythm (meaning there are P and T-waves for every QRS complex) and a slow heart rate (less than 60 beats per minute). Etiologies of sinus bradycardia include both physiologic and pathologic conditions. Endurance athletes often have physiologically lower resting heart rates due to increased vagal tone from exercise conditioning. Pathologic conditions include hypothyroidism, inferior wall myocardial infarction, anorexia nervosa, and the Cushing reflex. Additional etiologies include medications such as ꞵ-blocking agents, opiates, parasympathetic agents, digoxin, and antiarrhythmic agents such as amiodarone.    

Treatment involves correcting the underlying etiology and initiating targeted therapy in symptomatic patients, such as those experiencing lightheadedness, dizziness, or shortness of breath. Patients should first be treated with the antimuscarinic agent atropine. In those who fail medical management, surgical placement of a pacemaker in the right atrium should be considered.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased vagal tone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of hypothyroidism, he is currently medicated with recombinant thyroid hormone. Thus it is unlikely this patient’s sinus bradycardia is due to hypothyroidism.
❌ Inferior wall myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Sinus bradycardia can manifest due to an inferior wall myocardial infarction and subsequent ischemia to the SA and AV node. However, this patient has no chest pain, ST-elevations, or evidence of Q-waves in the inferior leads. 
❌ Obstructive sleep apnea:
Incorrect: Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with sinus bradycardia through vagal stimulation. This patient does not have clinical features of obstructive sleep apnea (e.g., daytime sleepiness, elevated BMI), thus making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Increased intracranial pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intracranial pressure can be caused by ischemic stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage, or cerebral trauma. It results in the Cushing triad, which is characterized by bradycardia, hypertension, and irregular breathing.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. He has a history of asthma and feels like he is currently “having a flare up” due to seasonal allergies. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler at home. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 122/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% O2 on room air. There are faint end expiratory wheezing bilaterally, and the electrocardiogram from triage is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s electrocardiographic findings?

choices.text: Pre-excitation through an accessory bypass tract
Enhanced automaticity from atrial non-sinus node sites

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a mild asthma exacerbation and has an electrocardiogram demonstrating beat-to-beat variation in the P-P interval and an irregular ventricular rate. These findings are consistent with sinus arrhythmia.   

Sinus arrhythmia is a normal physiologic variant of sinus rhythm and is due to changes in vagal tone throughout the respiratory cycle. As patients inspire, vagal tone decreases and heart rate increases. With subsequent onset of expiration, vagal tone is restored, leading to a decrease in heart rate. On an electrocardiograph, this condition manifests with variations in the P-P interval of more than 120 ms (3 small boxes), normal sinus P-waves with a constant morphology, and a constant P-R interval.  



Option Analysis

✅ Changes in vagal tone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits :
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation is defined electrocardiographically as irregularly irregular QRS complexes with absent P-waves. The condition arises due to the presence of multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits. In contrast, this patient has a regular rhythm and P-waves are present.
❌ Pre-excitation through an accessory bypass tract:
Incorrect: Pre-excitation syndromes, such as Wolff-Parkinson White syndrome, are characterized by the presence of an accessory bypass tract (e.g. bundle of Kent). Electrocardiographically, these conditions are characterized by delta waves, broad QRS complexes, and short PR intervals. 
❌ Metabolic abnormality:
Incorrect: Metabolic abnormalities such as hypomagnesemia or hypokalemia can produce premature ventricular complexes or a prolonged QT interval. However, metabolic disturbances are not associated with sinus arrhythmia. 
❌ Enhanced automaticity from atrial non-sinus node sites:
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. The condition results from enhanced automaticity at non-sinus node sites.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a witnessed syncopal episode. The patient’s parents report they had just finished dinner when their son spontaneously passed out. The patient does not recall the event and had no prodromal features. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications, use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. Electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

If left untreated this patient is at risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and cardiac arrest

questions.solution:
This otherwise young, healthy patient presents after a witnessed episode of drop syncope without prodrome features. The screening electrocardiogram demonstrates the classic features of Brugada syndrome, including “coved” ST segments (see Figure 1). Without appropriate treatment, patients with Brugada syndrome are at high risk of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death.   

Brugada syndrome is a rare, autosomal dominant sodium channelopathy that tends to affect males of Asian descent. The condition is most commonly attributed to mutations in the gene SCN5A, which is responsible for the cardiac sodium channel. Mutations in this gene result in a decrease of sodium ion flow during cardiac conduction, predisposing patients to ventricular arrhythmias--notably polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.  

The typical electrocardiogram for Brugada syndrome demonstrates coved ST segment elevation >2mm in >1 of V1-V3 followed by a negative T wave, which can also appear as a pseudo-right bundle branch block with the widened QRS presenting similar to a RSR’ configuration. Patients who have these electrocardiographic features and a corresponding clinical history should undergo treatment with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator to prevent sudden cardiac death from associated ventricular arrhythmias.  

Figure 1: Classic electrocardiogram findings for Brugada syndrome  

 


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons 

Option Analysis

✅ Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and cardiac arrest:
Correct: See main explanation  
❌ Atrial fibrillation and embolic stroke:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation and embolic stroke do not typically occur from long-standing Brugada syndrome. It is more likely in patients with long-standing, untreated hypertension and coronary artery disease.
❌ Third degree heart block:
Incorrect: Third degree heart block occurs when the atria and ventricles beat independently of one another and occurs more commonly due to coronary ischemia. Third degree heart block is not a well documented complication of Brugada syndrome.   
❌ Cor pulmonale:
Incorrect: Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right ventricular failure; it has multiple well documented causes including pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and pulmonary embolism.   
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy has multiple well known causes including hypertension, chronic alcohol use, beri-beri syndrome, and Chagas disease. Brugada syndrome is not a well established etiology of dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a witnessed syncopal episode. According to EMS, the patient was walking across the street when he suddenly collapsed. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, prior myocardial infarction, and a twenty pack year smoking history. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 202/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 82/62 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient is altered, pale, and has skin that is cool to the touch. Electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Based on this patient’s clinical presentation, this cardiac activity is likely the result of which of the following pathophysiologic processes?

choices.text: Re-entrant conduction below or within the bundle of His
Aberrant conduction through the bundle of Kent
Enhanced automaticity from the tricuspid annulus
Reentry circuit within the AV node

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a witnessed syncopal episode with unstable vital signs and electrocardiogram demonstrating monomorphic ventricular tachycardia in the setting of a history of coronary artery disease. Of the answer choices listed, the most likely etiology of this patient’s arrhythmia is an aberrant re-entry mechanism at or below the bundle of His.   

Ventricular tachycardia refers to an ectopic focus of electrical activity within the ventricle. The condition is electrocardiographically characterized by a rapid heart rate (>100 beats per minute) and wide QRS complexes (>120 ms). In general, ventricular tachycardia is further subdivided into monomorphic and polymorphic forms.  

Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia presents with QRS complexes that have a uniform appearance--meaning all of the QRS complexes are identical. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia is classically associated with myocardial scarring, acute myocardial infarction, or structural heart disease. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia is characterized by multiple ventricular foci and resultant QRS complexes that vary in amplitude, axis, and duration. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia can be associated with cardiac ischemia, although it is more commonly due to underlying metabolic derangements, medication toxicities, or inherited channelopathies (e.g., Brugada syndrome, Romano-Ward syndrome).  

Option Analysis

✅ Re-entrant conduction below or within the bundle of His:
Correct: See main explanation  
❌ Aberrant conduction through the bundle of Kent:
Incorrect: Pre-excitation syndromes such as Wolff-Parkinson White (WPW) are characterized by an accessory bypass tract. WPW is electrocardiographically characterized by a delta wave, broad QRS complexes, and short PR interval.   
❌ Enhanced automaticity from the tricuspid annulus :
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Patients with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia; however, this patient’s rhythm is regular, and the QRS complexes are wide.   
❌ Multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation is defined electrocardiographically as irregularly irregular QRS complexes with absent p-waves; the impulse originates from multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits. This patient's rhythm is regular, and the QRS complexes are wide.   
❌ Reentry circuit within the AV node:
Incorrect: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia presents with a heart rate ranging between 150 to 250 beats per minute, a narrow QRS complex, and in some cases, absent p-waves. This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates wide QRS complexes.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old female presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. She is concerned her “COPD is flaring up.” Past medical history is notable for hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and type II diabetes mellitus. She has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for twenty years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 104/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient is currently speaking in three to four word sentences and demonstrates increased work of breathing. There are bilateral rales throughout the lung fields, and the electrocardiogram from triage is shown below:  


Based on this patient's electrocardiogram, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with a COPD exacerbation and an electrocardiogram that demonstrates an irregular tachycardia, with three distinct P-wave morphologies. These features are most consistent with multifocal atrial tachycardia.  

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is an electrocardiographic diagnosis that arises due to enhanced automaticity in non-sinus node sites of either the left or right atrium. On electrocardiogram, MAT manifests as an irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. MAT is commonly mistaken for atrial fibrillation. However, careful evaluation of the above ECG demonstrates varying P-wave morphologies; whereas in atrial fibrillation P-waves are absent.

Nearly 60% of patients with MAT have underlying pulmonary disease, most commonly COPD. In addition, MAT is associated with heart disease, metabolic disturbances, and pulmonary embolism. Treatment is aimed at correcting the underlying cause, as the arrhythmia is often resistant to cardioversion or temporary rate control.      



Option Analysis

✅ Multifocal atrial tachycardia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrial flutter:
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is defined by atrial depolarization occurring at a rate of 250 to 350 beats/min. It is usually caused by an atrial reentry circuit that runs around the tricuspid annulus. The condition is characterized by "flutter waves," which have a sawtooth appearance, and the presence of multiple P-waves between QRS complexes. 
❌ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia  :
Incorrect: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is defined as a regular rhythm with a rate ranging between 150 to 250 beats per minute, a narrow QRS complex, and absent P-waves. In contrast, P-waves are seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram.
❌ Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is defined as an abnormally fast heart rate with irregularly irregular QRS complexes and absent P-waves. However, P-waves are present on this patient’s electrocardiogram, making atrial fibrillation unlikely.
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia is characterized by a fast (>100 beats per minutes) rate, regular rhythm, and an identifiable P-wave before every QRS complex. Sinus tachycardia would not, however, manifest with the variable P-wave morphologies seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old female presents to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset palpitations. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. The patient has had similar episodes in the past, and they self-resolved without treatment. However, the symptoms today have persisted for longer than usual. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 172/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 110/71 mmHg. Initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 
 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following features of this patient's electrocardiogram can be used to localize the anatomic origin of this arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
This young, otherwise healthy patient presents with sudden-onset palpitations and an electrocardiogram that demonstrates a regular, narrow complex tachycardia with absent P-waves. These findings are most consistent with a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. In general, the distinguishing feature of supraventricular tachycardias is the presence of narrow QRS complexes.  

Supraventricular tachycardias refer to a subset of fast arrhythmias that originate above the ventricles, or above the bundle of His. Supraventricular arrhythmias are classified into several main types: those of sinus origin, reentrant tachycardias, ectopic rhythms, and pre-excitation syndromes (e.g. Wolff-Parkinson White).  

With the exception of Wolff-Parkinson White, supraventricular arrhythmias are characterized by narrow QRS complexes (<100 ms). This electrocardiographic finding is reflective of rapid depolarization of the ventricles. In contrast, ventricular arrhythmias will have wide QRS complexes due to slower depolarization. Differentiation between supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias remains an important diagnostic consideration, as the treatment and risk of degeneration into ventricular fibrillation or cardiac arrest rises substantially with arrhythmias of ventricular origin.  



Option Analysis

✅ QRS complex duration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ QT interval :
Incorrect: The QT interval can provide information regarding the presence of concomitant metabolic disturbances, medication side effects, and inherited QT channelopathy. It can also predict a patient’s risk of developing torsades de pointes. However, the QT interval does not provide meaningful information regarding an arrhythmia’s anatomic site of origin.
❌ PR interval   :
Incorrect: The PR interval provides information regarding interventricular conduction, metabolic disturbance, or presence of an accessory bypass tract. 
❌ P wave morphology :
Incorrect: The presence of P-waves can help differentiate between supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias, with the latter more likely to not present with P-waves. However, evaluating for the presence of P-waves is not as useful as measuring QRS complex width when determining an arrhythmia’s site of origin.
❌ Axis :
Incorrect: The axis of a patient’s electrocardiogram can be used to differentiate between left and right heart strain or hypertrophy. It does not provide meaningful information about an arrhythmia’s site of origin.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old male undergoes coronary artery bypass grafting due to severe symptomatic coronary artery disease. The surgery is uncomplicated, and the patient is admitted to the cardiothoracic intensive care unit for hemodynamic monitoring. Overnight, a rapid response is called after a tachyarrhythmia was noted on the patient’s telemetry strip. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 134/72 mmHg. He has incisional chest pain but is otherwise asymptomatic. The patient’s electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Based on this patient's clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This patient presents after cardiac surgery with an electrocardiogram demonstrating characteristic flutter waves with a 3:1 and 4:1 AV nodal block. These findings are most consistent with atrial flutter.  
 
Atrial flutter is a common tachydysrhythmia that usually arises due to a reentry circuit near the tricuspid annulus. It results in an atrial rate of approximately 300 beats per minute with subsequent ventricular depolarizations of approximately 150 beats per minute. Identifying atrial flutter is dependent on the recognition of characteristic "flutter waves," which are most commonly found in the inferior leads and take on a saw-tooth appearance. Atrial flutter will also demonstrate an atrio-ventricular conduction ratio, meaning that every X number of atrial beats results in a single ventricular depolarization. For example, a 3:1 conduction ratio indicates three atrial beats for every one ventricular beat.  

Etiologies of atrial flutter include underlying metabolic disturbance, structural heart disease, pulmonary embolism, pericarditis, and recent cardiac surgery. When symptomatic, patients typically present with shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and light-headedness. Treatment is targeted at correcting the underlying etiology and achieving rate control. Atrial flutter is often more resistant to rate controlling medications, and thus many patients will need to undergo catheter directed ablation.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Atrial flutter  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia:
Incorrect: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is defined as a regular rhythm with a rate ranging between 150 to 250 beats per minute, a narrow QRS complex, and absent P-waves. In contrast, P-waves are seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram .
❌ Multifocal atrial tachycardia :
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Patients with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia. However, this patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates a “sawtooth pattern,” which is more consistent with atrial flutter.
❌ Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is defined as an abnormally fast heart rate with irregularly irregular QRS complexes and absent P-waves. In contrast, P-waves are seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram.
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia is characterized by a fast (>100 beats per minutes) rate, regular rhythm, and an identifiable P-wave before every QRS complex. It would not, however, manifest with the “sawtooth pattern” seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram .

questions.text:
A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a confirmed cardiac arrest in the field. Per EMS, the patient was found down by several bystanders without a pulse, and CPR was initiated immediately. The patient has no past medical history and is not on any medications. He is currently without a pulse, and CPR is ongoing. His 12 lead electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons   

The patient is shocked multiple times and dies despite resuscitation efforts. Post-mortem analysis is most likely to demonstrate which of the following as the etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient sustained a witnessed cardiac arrest and cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was initiated. The electrocardiogram demonstrates findings consistent with ventricular fibrillation, of which the most common culprit is underlying coronary artery disease.  

Ventricular fibrillation represents the most lethal arrhythmia, characterized by completely disorganized electrical activity of the heart without discernable p-waves, QRS complexes, or t-waves. During ventricular fibrillation the heart is “quivering” and unable to provide meaningful cardiac output or a pulse. It is commonly preceded by ventricular tachycardia and will result in asystole and death unless immediately treated with CPR and defibrillation. Despite these interventions, the arrhythmia still carries an overall poor prognosis.

The etiologies of ventricular fibrillation are multiple, but it is most commonly due to severe coronary artery disease, plaque rupture, and subsequent myocardial infarction. Other less common etiologies include electrolyte abnormalities such as hyperkalemia, major trauma, near drowning, or associated underlying cardiac diseases such as cardiomyopathy, Brugada syndrome, myocarditis, or inherited long QT-syndromes.      

Option Analysis

✅ Multi-vessel coronary artery disease:
Correct: See main explanation  
❌ Saddle pulmonary embolism :
Incorrect: A large pulmonary embolism can trigger ventricular tachycardia and subsequent ventricular fibrillation/cardiac arrest if enough right heart strain occurs; however, it is not the most common etiology of cardiac arrest.   
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy is a common culprit of ventricular fibrillation arrest, but it is not the most common etiology in the overall population.   
❌ Hypomagnesemia :
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia portends to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and torsade de pointes. These ventricular arrhythmias can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation arrest; however, underlying coronary artery disease is a more likely culprit.   
❌ Pericardial effusion:
Incorrect: Pericardial tamponade can result in obstructive shock and subsequent ventricular fibrillation arrest. Pericardial tamponade presents with muffled heart tones in the setting of a history of trauma, rheumatologic disease, malignancy, or uremia.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations. He states he drank his morning coffee, went out for a jog, but he suddenly became lightheaded and noted a fluttering sensation in his chest. He had a similar episode in the past, which self-resolved without intervention. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 175/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical exam is otherwise unremarkable, and initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Based on this patient's clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This young, otherwise healthy patient presents with sudden onset palpitations and an electrocardiogram that demonstrates a regular, narrow complex tachycardia with absent P-waves. These findings are most consistent with the diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.   

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia refers to any supraventricular tachycardia (arising above the bundle of His) with abrupt onset and offset. While there are multiple subsets, this arrhythmia is most commonly caused by atrio-ventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), which results in a reentrant circuit that loops within the AV node. Patients with this disorder are typically symptomatic and may notice subtle palpitations, dizziness, and lightheadedness. Patients with underlying heart disease may also experience chest pain and shortness of breath. This arrhythmia commonly occurs in patients without any history of cardiac disease, although alcohol and coffee can trigger the arrhythmia via inhibition of adenosine reuptake.  

On an electrocardiogram, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is defined as a regular rhythm with a rate between 150 to 250 beats per minute, a narrow QRS complex, and absence of normal P-waves. Sometimes, retrograde P-waves can be seen after the QRS complex; however, these are usually buried. First-line treatment consists of vagal maneuvers (e.g., placing an ice pack on the face, having the patient bear down or blow into a straw). If these maneuvers fail, adenosine should be administered. This medication terminates the arrhythmia by decreasing AV nodal conduction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrial flutter:
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is defined by atrial depolarization occurring at a rate of 250 to 350 beats/min. It is usually caused by an atrial reentry circuit that runs around the tricuspid annulus. The condition is characterized by "flutter waves," which have a sawtooth appearance, and the presence of multiple P-waves between QRS complexes. 
❌ Multifocal atrial tachycardia :
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Individuals with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia. However, this patient’s rhythm is regular and P-waves are absent.   
❌ Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) will manifest on electrocardiography with an abnormally fast heart rate, irregularly spaced QRS complexes, and absent P-waves. In contrast, the QRS complexes on this patient’s electrocardiography are equally spaced. 
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia is defined as a fast heart rate (>100 beats per minutes), regular rhythm, and an identifiable P-wave before every QRS complex. In contrast, no P-waves can be seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to lightheadedness. The patient was drinking coffee this morning, noticed a “fluttering” sensation in his chest, and subsequently felt lightheaded. He is otherwise asymptomatic and has not seen a physician in many years. He smokes one to two cigarettes per day and drinks a glass of wine with dinner nightly. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 134/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 142/92 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical examination is notable for an obese male in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary exam is without evidence of gallops, rubs, murmurs, or rales. Initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s electrocardiographic findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations, lightheadedness, and an electrocardiogram demonstrating an irregularly irregular fast rhythm without identifiable P-waves. These findings are consistent with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Of the risk factors listed, a history of untreated hypertensive heart disease is the most common underlying risk factor for the development of this arrhythmia.  

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia in clinical practice and results from unpatterned depolarization of atrial tissues caused by multiple micro-reentry circuits. These reentry circuits are most commonly the result of progressive fibrosis and atrial dilation. Electrocardiographically, atrial fibrillation is characterized by irregularly irregular QRS complexes with absent P-waves. When rapid ventricular response occurs, with rates >100 beats per minute, diastolic filling and subsequent cardiac output may decrease. These changes result in symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and lightheadedness.  

Atrial fibrillation has multiple etiologies and risk factors, but the most common ones are hypertensive heart disease and coronary artery disease. Other causes include hyperthyroidism, excess alcohol consumption, valvular heart disease, and congestive heart failure.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Hypertensive heart disease :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperthyroidism :
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism is associated with new-onset atrial fibrillation. However, this patient does not have a history consistent with this diagnosis (e.g., presence of goiter, history of Graves disease, history of autoimmune disorders).
❌ Obstructive sleep apnea:
Incorrect: To date, studies are inconclusive regarding the association between obstructive sleep apnea and atrial fibrillation. 
❌ Caffeine consumption:
Incorrect: Caffeine consumption may be associated with certain arrhythmias, such as paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. However, it is not associated with atrial fibrillation.
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism can cause new-onset atrial fibrillation. However, this patient lacks risk factors for pulmonary embolism, such as recent surgery, long distance travel, or active malignancy.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations. The patient was in the park jogging when he suddenly felt lightheaded, dizzy, and noted a pounding sensation in his chest. The symptoms resolved prior to arrival, and he now feels back to his baseline. Medical history is otherwise noncontributory, and he does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. The electrocardiogram from triage is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Pre-excitation through the bundle of Kent
Macro-reentrant circuit at the tricuspid annulus
Enhanced automaticity from atrial non-sinus node sites

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient presents after a near-syncopal event during exertion. The electrocardiogram demonstrated a slurred upstroke of the QRS complex, wide QRS complexes, and a short PR interval. These findings are most consistent with Wolff-Parkinson White syndrome.   

Wolff-Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome refers to an accessory pre-excitation syndrome that arises when electrical signals are able to bypass the AV node. The most common accessory pathway in this disorder is the bundle of Kent, which rests on the infero-lateral aspect of the right atrium. Ventricular pre-excitation via this pathway can result in reentrant tachycardias, since it does not have the same physiologic brakes as the AV node. If these reentrant tachycardias are sustained, they can result in ventricular fibrillation or sudden cardiac death. Definitive treatment involves catheter directed ablation of the bypass tract to facilitate normal conduction through the AV node.  

On electrocardiogram, the disease is characterized by three distinct features: 1) a slurred upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave), 2) wide QRS complexes (>120 ms), and 3) a short PR interval (<120 ms).  

However, one must take care when diagnosing this condition, since electrocardiographically it may not always present at regular rates, but rather with sustained reentrant tachycardias. This phenomenon allows for potential misinterpretation of this deadly arrhythmia as atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response or paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia.    



Option Analysis

✅ Pre-excitation through the bundle of Kent :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Macro-reentrant circuit at the tricuspid annulus :
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is defined by atrial depolarization occurring at a rate of 250 to 350 beats/min. It is usually caused by an atrial reentry circuit that runs around the tricuspid annulus. The condition is characterized by "flutter waves", which have a sawtooth appearance, and the presence of multiple P-waves between QRS complexes. 
❌ Multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits :
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation manifest on electrocardiography with irregularly irregular QRS complexes and absent P-waves. In contrast, the QRS complexes on this patient’s electrocardiograph occur at regular intervals, and P-waves are present.
❌ Enhanced automaticity from atrial non-sinus node sites:
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Patients with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia. However, this patient’s rhythm is regular, and the P-waves are of similar morphology. 
❌ Abnormal ventricular repolarization:
Incorrect: Torsades de pointes results from abnormal ventricular repolarization. On electrocardiogram, it is characterized by a ventricular rate greater than 200 beats/min and an undulating QRS axis, with the polarity of the complexes appearing to shift about the baseline. These findings are not present on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old female is brought to the emergency department after exhibiting disorganized behavior and vomiting. Per EMS, the patient was yelling and smoking marijuana on the street, after which she began vomiting large amounts of non-bilious non-bloody emesis. She was given several doses of ondansetron and haloperidol prior to arrival, which improved the symptoms. Past medical history is notable for cyclic vomiting syndrome, schizophrenia, and hypothyroidism for which she takes metoclopramide, risperidone, and levothyroxine, respectively. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and uses marijuana several times per week. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 137/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a disheveled woman who is sleeping comfortably in bed. While the nurses are attempting to place an IV, telemetry displays the following finding:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely precipitant of this patient’s telemetry finding?
questions.solution:
This patient has received multiple anti-dopaminergic medications (e.g., metoclopramide, haloperidol, risperidone), which are known to prolong the QT interval. The telemetry strip demonstrates torsade de pointes, a subtype of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.  

Torsade de pointes means “twisting of the points” and is a subtype of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia defined by a ventricular rate >200 beats per minute, undulating QRS axis, and paroxysms of < 90 seconds. The major risk factor for developing torsade de pointes is QT interval prolongation, of which there are numerous causes.  

The most common causes include electrolyte abnormalities such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia and medications such as class IA and IC antiarrhythmics, antidepressants, antidopaminergics, antiemetics, and anticonvulsants. Less commonly, acquired conditions such as Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (associated with deafness, autosomal recessive) or Romano-Ward syndrome (normal hearing, autosomal dominant) can cause QT prolongation. Treatment of torsade de pointes involves empiric intravenous magnesium sulfate or cardioversion and overdrive pacing for patients with sustained torsade de pointes and unstable vital signs.  

Option Analysis

✅ Antagonism of D2 receptors:
Correct: See main explanation  
❌ Hypomagnesemia :
Incorrect: Alcoholism and gastrointestinal losses can result in hypomagnesemia and subsequent QT prolongation, resulting in torsade de pointes. However, this patient has no history of significant alcohol use, and hypomagnesemia is more likely to occur due to diarrhea than vomiting. Given this patient’s clinical history, overuse of anti-dopaminergic drugs is a more likely precipitant of this patient’s telemetry findings.   
❌ Autosomal recessive QT prolongation syndrome:
Incorrect: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is an autosomal recessive QT prolongation syndrome associated with sensorineural hearing loss. This patient has no history of hearing deficits.  
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Severe untreated hypothyroidism, usually in the setting myxedema coma, can lead to torsade de pointes. This is unlikely given the patient is being treated with levothyroxine and lacks clinical findings of severe hypothyroidism (e.g., bradycardia, weakness, dry skin).   
❌ Marijuana use:
Incorrect: Marijuana use, in and of itself, is not associated with QT prolongation.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with lightheadedness. Since last night, she has felt fatigued and has noticed that every time she stands, she feels like she is about to pass out. She reports feeling short of breath after climbing a set of stairs for the past week. One month ago, she returned from summer camp in New Jersey, after which she began to develop fatigue and headaches. She takes acetaminophen for the headaches. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 40/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. She appears exhausted. Physical exam shows regular bradycardia without murmurs. No skin lesions are seen. An ECG is obtained and shows the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following species most likely transmitted this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ECG shows a third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block, also called complete heart block. In third-degree AV block, none of the electrical impulses are conducted through the AV node. Cutoff from one another, the atria and ventricles (which both have their own pacemakers) begin to contract independently of one another, known as AV dissociation. This desynchronization of the heart chambers can reduce cardiac output dramatically, leading to syncope or even sudden cardiac death. On ECG, the P-waves and QRS complexes have no relation to each other, each occurring at their own rates. Initial management of all patients with third-degree AV block involves the placement of transcutaneous pacer pads or transvenous pacing with chronotropes (atropine) to ensure adequate cardiac output. If no reversible cause is found, patients will require permanent pacemaker implantation.  



This patient’s history of outdoor activities in the northeastern United States (eg, New Jersey, Connecticut) is concerning for Lyme disease. Transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi (the spirochete responsible for Lyme disease) occurs through tick bites from Ixodes scapularis. Early localized Lyme disease may cause fatigue, anorexia, and headache days to weeks after infection. Although inoculation is usually associated with erythema migrans, the majority of patients do not notice this rash. Lyme carditis represents early disseminated disease, which occurs a few months after infection.
